newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch say yet to decide on Schiphol privatisation.
newsitem.headline: Dutch say yet to decide on Schiphol privatisation.

text.p: The Dutch government has yet to take a decision on the privatisation of Amsterdam's Schiphol Airport, a transport ministry spokeswoman said on Wednesday.
She was responding to Dutch media reports that the cabinet had rejected a proposal put forward last week by transport minister Annemarie Jorritsma and finance minister Gerrit Zalm.
The Financieele Dagblad newspaper reported that the cabinet had rejected their proposal as untimely while debate proceeded about whether to expand Schiphol or build a new airport.

"The reports in the newpapers are false. The cabinet has discussed the matter but needs more time to consider the plans, that is all. They will meet again next week," a spokeswoman for the transport ministry said.
"This was the first step in the discussions and after the cabinet has made its decision, the matter will go before parliament," the spokeswoman said.

The government holds 76 percent of Schiphol, the Netherlands' main international airport, and is considering cutting this to a minority. Amsterdam city council owns 22 percent of Schiphol and Rotterdam city council two percent.
